> CJDNS is like a distributed, shared VPN with multiple entry points where every participant can reach any other participant. All participants use addresses from the fc00::/8 network (reserved IPv6 range). Installation and configuration is done outside of applications, similarly to VPN (either in the host/OS or on the network router).\n\nSorry but this doesn't look good enough to add one more ne

FWIW, BIP155 does already reserve a network ID for CJDNS (that's not an argument either way of course, but perhaps the BIP's author have opinions on this too). @laanwj?

I did some research about CJDNS, GNUnet and Yggdrasil.\n\nWill read more about these networks and also compare with few others in next few days. Shared initial thoughts and things I did here: https://blockchaincommons.github.io/Bitcoin-Camouflage//blog/cjdns/

Yes, BIP155 and Tor v3 implementation were both fairly deep changes. I2P was also extensive. This change set is relatively tiny, I've done a first review pass, and in terms of time it was well under 10% that of any of the BIP155 impl, Tor v3, and I2P for me.

How about simply requiring a "`%cjdns`" suffix on CJDNS addresses?

> How about simply requiring a "`%cjdns`" suffix on CJDNS addresses?

Internally the addresses are already distinguished in the `CNetAddr` class by having `m_net` set to either `NET_IPV6` or `NET_CJDNS`.

For representation purposes:
* On output: yes, we can print CJDNS ones with `%cjdns` suffix
* On input: we can recognize e.g. `fc00::123` as reserved-IPv6 and `fc00::123%cjdns` as CJD

> FWIW, BIP155 does already reserve a network ID for CJDNS (that's not an argument either way of course, but perhaps the BIP's author have opinions on this too). @laanwj?\n\nFrom what I understood back then is that CJDNS is fairly pervasive in mesh networking. You can peer it over arbitrary networks and physical layers but you'll still have a global address *from the viewpoint of software*.  Wit

> Should the cjdns tests in `feature_proxy.py` be behind the `self.have_ipv6` conditional?

That's only required if the Socks5 proxy has IPv6 address (`::1`). For CJDNS tests, `self.serv1` is used which listens at `127.0.0.1`.

It is not a public/exported function for everybody to use and as such does not have a declaration in `net.h`.

> everything ok with the endianness here?

Good question. I think it is:

```
$ gdb --args ./src/test/test_bitcoin --run_test="net_tests/cnetaddr_unserialize_v2"
(gdb) b src/test/net_tests.cpp:534
(gdb) r
(gdb) x/16xb addr.m_addr._union.indirect_contents.indirect
0x803994ae0:	0xfc	0x00	0x00	0x01	0x00	0x02	0x00	0x03
0x803994ae8:	0x00	0x04	0x00	0x05	0x00	0x06	0x00	0x07
(gdb) p/
18b612149ba044b593087ae6678753e6a82bfa0b\n\nCool, so this still allows us to peer with local ipv6 addresses under 0xfc provided we don't pass `-cjdnsreachable`.

aa9ca9bf1701cf9d1241622ec2ba069c8fc40d53\n\nMaybe the bit math here is tripping me up, but if we're using for `/32` groups for IPv6 below, why wouldn't we just discard the constant byte at the head of cjdns addresses (`0xfc`) and set `nBits = 32 - 8 = 24`?

Yes. Local IPv6 `fc00::/8` peers are mutually exclusive with CJDNS at the operating system level.\n\nActually you will connect to a local IPv6 `fc...` address even if you pass `-cjdnsreachable` and if CJDNS is not set up in the OS. But that would be mis-configuring bitcoin, it will mistakenly think that that is somebody from the CJDNS network.

The `/32` logic for IPv6 is based on the assumption that it is easy to acquire addresses with same prefix. E.g. it is likely that
```
aaaa:aaaa:3:4:5:6:7:8
aaaa:aaaa:3:4:5:6:7:9
aaaa:aaaa:3:4:5:1:1:1
```
belong to the same actor, while
```
aaaa:aaaa:3:4:5:6:7:8
bbbb:bbbb:3:4:5:6:7:8
```
are unlikely to belong to the same actor.

This assumption is not true for any of Tor,
